utterances: Louis Picone is the author of the book ""The President Is Dead!"" - which recounts the funerals of all the deceased presidents.
Citizens would line up.
They'd wait for hours.
Sometimes, hundreds of thousands of people would line up to pass by the coffin to see the remains of Abraham Lincoln.
It got even more complicated once Lincoln's body reached Springfield.
He was buried and reburied many times before he was finally placed in his current tomb.
Historians really lose track of how many times his body was moved over the years.
It's a ballpark of about 15 times that his coffin was moved over the years.
The last president to die in office was John F.
Kennedy.
His 1963 assassination traumatized the country.
Again - Matt Costello.
This was the first state funeral, really, that was, you know, put on television.
So you had the statistic of something like 90 to 95 percent of Americans tuned in to watch the funeral.
Kennedy was buried at Arlington National Cemetery, which is a real exception.
William Howard Taft is the only other ex-president buried in Arlington, just across the Potomac River from Washington.
And just one president is buried in Washington - Woodrow Wilson, who's at the National Cathedral.
Costello says we're seeing a new trend in recent decades.
All of the modern presidents who have modern presidential libraries are buried along with their wives at the presidential libraries.
George H.W.
Bush will be buried next to his wife, Barbara, at his presidential library in College Station, Texas.
Greg Myre, NPR News, Washington.

MARINE CHAMBER ORCHESTRA PERFORMANCE OF ""BATTLE HYMN OF THE REPUBLIC"")
(Singing) Mine eyes have seen the glory of the coming of the Lord.
He is trampling out the vintage where the grapes of wrath...
And it's time to play The Puzzle.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
Joining us as always is Will Shortz.
He's puzzle editor of The New York Times and WEEKEND EDITION's puzzlemaster.
Good morning, Will.
Good morning, Lulu.
Welcome back.
The Model S is initially only about a 20,000-vehicle production.
So we're going to be occupying a little corner, but there's a lot of room for growth and in the long-term, we certainly intend to use the full capacity of NUMMI.
Car industry experts say the deal gives Tesla a huge lead in mass producing an electric car.
And for $50 million, Toyota gets access to Tesla's power-train technology.
But Toyota may get something more: Some goodwill from the public when it really needs it, says Jeremy Anwyl, the CEO of Edmunds.com.
I think they really score a lot of political points by keeping that plant going.
They may not say that, but my suspicion is that's their driving motivation and I think that's a very smart move.
UC-Berkeley labor expert Harley Shaiken said there's tremendous potential for Toyota at a time when it's has fallen behind Nissan and Chevrolet in the electric car market.
In the Fremont plant, the old Corolla line, which worked so well, is still there.
That would mean a rapid transition is possible to building an electric Corolla or even a hybrid Corolla in Fremont.
That could be a game-changer for the industry and certainly for jobs.
Tesla's CEO Elon Musk says he plans to start production of the Model S within two years and hire up to 1,000 workers in Fremont.
And he said he wouldn't encourage or oppose the workers organizing a union.
Richard Gonzales, NPR News, Fremont, California.
Ever since the 9/11 attacks, U.S.
intelligence agencies has been trying to find agents who speak critical languages like Arabic or Farsi.
They launched a $1.5 million recruiting campaign that seems to have paid off - the newest class of would-be FBI agents is described as the bureau's most language diverse ever.
NPR's FBI correspondent Dina Temple-Raston reports.
Four of the FBI's newest recruits are sitting in steel-reinforced police car with crash helmets on.
They're listening to supervisory special agent Lee Wetzel(ph), who is teaching them how to drive like they do in cop shows.
Again, the hardest part about this is being able to keep that speed under control.
(Soundbite of beeping)
Wetzel accelerates and begins weaving the car through series of orange cones spaced 17 feet apart.
The recruits instinctively reach for the steel bars reinforcing the inside of the car.
At the risk of throwing you around too much (unintelligible) you got a pretty good speed going...
Wetzel pulls the car over, turns around, and asks for volunteers.
The recruits are still clutching the metal bars around them.
This might all seemed like part of a very ordinary day at FBI training center in Quantico, Virginia, and in some ways it is.
But there is one important difference.
The men and women sitting in these cars in their matching navy blue shirts and khaki pants are what the FBI calls language hires.
They are first or second-generation Americans who speak languages like Arabic or Chinese or Russian.
Last December we decided we needed to dedicate even more emphasis not only on recruiting but on tracking the language candidates.
That's Gwen Hubbard of the FBI.
She's been one of the forces behind the language recruitment effort.
With over 70,000 job applications pouring into the bureau a year, Hubbard said language applicants tended to get lost in the shuffle.
So the FBI created a different track to get them through the hiring process faster.
These particular candidates were on what we call our critical hire special agent list, which means they have these special skills.
We need them in like yesterday.
Let's do everything we can to get these individuals through the process as soon as we can.
Hubbard says there are about 300 candidates on that language critical hire list at any one time.
Islam(ph) is standing among a group of recruits waiting their turn behind the wheel of the FBI practice car.
The FBI asks that only the first name of the recruits be used to protect their identity.
Islam is 27 and grew up mostly in Detroit, Michigan.
He moved to the U.S.
from Cairo, Egypt, when he was 12 years old.
He speaks fluent Arabic and he says he's always had an eye on an FBI career.
Other than being a dream of mine as a little kid, of course, after obviously September 11 I feel like I have some assets as far as the language skills.
I can definitely give back to the country, which has been very good to me and my family.
Carl is 36, blond, and freckled - he grew up in Las Vegas, and then went to Brigham Young University where he majored in Mandarin Chinese.
After school he was a Chinese language tour guide at the Grand Canyon and then worked at a technology company.
And then he signed on to the FBI.
You know, I really thought it would be a great opportunity for me to utilize the Chinese skills that I had.
And I've always had a strong feeling that I wanted to do something, you know, to combat the evils that are in the world, and the FBI would provide that opportunity for me.
Victoria is 27, and she speaks Russian.
She came to the States from Russia to attend graduate school at University of Buffalo.
She said she has always considered law enforcement as a career, but after September 11th she felt that the FBI was the best fit.
She says that she wants to fight terrorism, and then she giggles and admits to another reason for joining the FBI.
Well, of course, everyone thinks it's cool.
It is cool, yes.
As proud as the FBI is of this class, they have even more to look forward to next month.
On August 5th they begin training a new class.
It has 18 new language hires.
Their hiring goal for the year is 51, and they're almost there.
Dina Temple-Raston, NPR News, Washington.
It wasn't until the rousing anthem ended that three members of the Seahawks jogged onto the field to join their teammates.
Like several other players around the league this past week, this trio skipped the anthem to send another message.
I spoke to one of the three, offensive tackle Duane Brown, after the game.
Birmingham, Alabama; Baltimore, Maryland; Memphis, Tennessee.
Those three cities were on the list in '04.
They did not return.
Well, my engineer and I are making little heartbroken faces right now because we're both from Baltimore.
But that's all right, we forgive you.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I'll have you know that no editors, actually, you know, we're all from different parts of the country and we all had our city that we were rooting for, and most of us were disappointed.
Chicago didn't make it, Detroit didn't make it, Los Angeles didn't make it.
